description: A public area with trees and paths where people can walk and relax.
A building where historical, artistic, or scientific objects are kept and shown.
An underground electric railway system in a city.
A small restaurant where you can buy drinks and simple meals.
An open public area in a city where people can gather.
A wide city street, often with trees along the sides.
A very tall building in a city.
A specific area within a city, often with a distinct character.
A very large and busy city, often an important cultural and economic center.
The basic systems and services, such as transport and power supplies, that a city needs to work effectively.
An extremely large city, typically with a population of over ten million people.
The process by which more and more people leave the countryside to live in cities.
A large area made up of several large cities and towns that have grown to join together.
The process by which wealthier people move into, renovate, and restore housing and sometimes businesses in urban neighborhoods.
A town or part of a large city, having its own local government.
A wide street or main thoroughfare.
Travel some distance between one's home and place of work on a regular basis.
A building or place that is easily recognized, especially one that you can use to judge where you are.
A narrow passageway between or behind buildings.
The principal church of a diocese, with which the bishop is officially associated.
The city or town that functions as the seat of government and administrative center of a country or region.
The front of a building, especially an imposing or decorative one.
A person walking rather than traveling in a vehicle.
A point or line common to lines or surfaces that intersect.
A statue, building, or other structure erected to commemorate a notable person or event.
